action.action-desc: Mr. Feenstra (for himself, Ms. Stevens, Mr. Crawford, Mr. Ellzey, Mr. Donalds, Mrs. Kim of California, Ms. Mace, Mr. Fitzpatrick, Mr. Yakym, Mr. Neguse, Mr. Williams of New York, Mr. Kean of New Jersey, Mr. Lucas, Ms. Lofgren, and Mr. Jackson of North Carolina) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Science, Space, and Technology

form.official-title: To amend the National Quantum Initiative Act to make certain additions relating to quantum modeling and simulation, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Quantum in Practice Act.

paragraph.text: Quantum computing has the potential to spur advancements in molecular modeling and simulation that will benefit Americans.
Quantum molecular simulations and modeling will enable scientists to study chemical elements and reactions with accuracy and speed that is far beyond the abilities of existing supercomputers.
Advances in molecular simulations and modeling would give researchers tools that could lead to breakthroughs across industries and sectors, including—

subparagraph.text: modeling the nitrogen fixation process utilized by bacteria, which could be used to develop synthetic fertilizers without the high energy and material costs of current methods, creating the next generation of fertilizers;
creating more effective medications and reducing harmful interactions or side effects;
developing new materials to increase energy storage capacity and create more powerful battery technologies;
creating materials for more durable protective gear for law enforcement and military; and

subsection.text: Section 2(6) of the National Quantum Initiative Act (15 U.S.C. 8801(6)) is amended by inserting modeling, simulation, after computing.
Section 401(b)(3) of such Act (15 U.S.C. 8851(b)(3)) is amended—
